newsitem.title: UK: UK's Standard Life to apply for banking licence.
newsitem.headline: UK's Standard Life to apply for banking licence.

text.p: British mutual life assurance company Standard Life said on Monday it would apply to the Bank of England for a banking licence with a view to attracting personal savings and providing mortgages.

In a statement, the Edinburgh-based group said it hoped Standard Life Banking Services Ltd, which would in time employ around 200 people, would be in the market "by the end of the year", reflecting the time it would take to receive BoE authority and to write the necessary systems.

A week ago the mutual group said reports that it was about to launch a new banking operation were "pure speculation". The opening of services such as savings, personal loans and mortgages will follow similar moves by Prudential Corp and Scottish Widows.
Standard Life said the move followed the appointment earlier this year of Jim Spowart who was formerly managing director of Direct Line Financial Services.
Spowart, now Standard Life's general manager banking services, said the group was "capable of becoming one of the major players in the personal banking and mortgage lending sectors".

"We shall build on Standard Life's existing reputation and with sophisticated and tailor-made computer systems will provide benefits to customers in the shape of extremely competitive products," he added.
